citations.narrative:
The facility is not following the written program of veterinary care (PVC) for dogs regarding the sampling and treatment of
parasites and other pests for the wolf-hybrids “Kieran” and “Tenali”.
The program of veterinary care (PVC) directs a combination heartworm prevention and deworming treatment to be
administered to the animals by sanctuary staff or trained volunteers approximately every 30 days, year-round. The
medical records for both dogs show that a dose of this medication was not administered for the month of August 2024.
The same medical records show that the veterinarian directed the animals to be treated with the flea and tick prevention
medication Bravecto as 1 chewable tablet by mouth once every 3 months. “Keiran” and Tenali” were only treated with one
dose of Bravecto on 3/31/24 and then again on 3/30/25.
The PVC also directs heartworm sampling tests be done on any animal that has not taken a preventative for 45 days or
more. According to the medical record (as noted above), “Kieran” and “Tenali” received a dose of heartworm prevention
on 7/7/2024 and did not receive the next dose until 9/1/2024, which is a lapse of 62 days. No heartworm test has been
performed as directed by the PVC for a lapse of 45 days or greater in receiving prevention medication.
Animals that miss monthly doses for blood and intestinal parasite prevention/treatment and external parasite prevention
could be at risk for contracting these parasites. Also, not performing follow-up tests as directed by the PVC, could lead to
undetected problems that can cause illness and infection in the wolf-hybrids.
The licensee must follow the program of vet care in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian
for the sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests. To be corrected from this day forward: April 16, 2025.

The medical records for the wolf-hybrids “Keiran” and “Tenali” are incomplete. On the Bravecto and Heartworm medical
records it shows that both animals were given something in food, but the name of the medication is not listed. These
medications were missing on “Keiran’s” record on 6/30/2024 and 7/7/24 and on “Tenali’s” record on 7/7/2024, 10/6/2024,
and 10/30/2024. Failure to record the names of treatments administered could lead to infection or illness of the animal.
The licensee must keep copies of medical records for dogs that name all vaccines and treatments administered and the
dates of administration. To be corrected from this day forward: April 16, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the written program of veterinary care (PVC) for dogs regarding the sampling and treatment of 
parasites and other pests for the wolf-hybrids “Kieran” and “Tenali”.  
The program of veterinary care (PVC) directs a combination heartworm prevention and deworming treatment to be 
administered to the animals by sanctuary staff or trained volunteers approximately every 30 days, year-round. The 
medical records for both dogs show that a dose of this medication was not administered for the month of August 2024.  
The same medical records show that the veterinarian directed the animals to be treated with the flea and tick prevention 
medication Bravecto as 1 chewable tablet by mouth once every 3 months. “Keiran” and Tenali” were only treated with one 
dose of Bravecto on 3/31/24 and then again on 3/30/25. 
The PVC also directs heartworm sampling tests be done on any animal that has not taken a preventative for 45 days or 
more. According to the medical record (as noted above), “Kieran” and “Tenali” received a dose of heartworm prevention 
on 7/7/2024 and did not receive the next dose until 9/1/2024, which is a lapse of 62 days. No heartworm test has been 
performed as directed by the PVC for a lapse of 45 days or greater in receiving prevention medication.  
Animals that miss monthly doses for blood and intestinal parasite prevention/treatment and external parasite prevention 
could be at risk for contracting these parasites. Also, not performing follow-up tests as directed by the PVC, could lead to 
undetected problems that can cause illness and infection in the wolf-hybrids.  
The licensee must follow the program of vet care in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian 
for the sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests. To be corrected from this day forward: April 16, 2025. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The medical records for the wolf-hybrids “Keiran” and “Tenali” are incomplete. On the Bravecto and Heartworm medical 
records it shows that both animals were given something in food, but the name of the medication is not listed. These 
medications were missing on “Keiran’s” record on 6/30/2024 and 7/7/24 and on “Tenali’s” record on 7/7/2024, 10/6/2024, 
and 10/30/2024. Failure to record the names of treatments administered could lead to infection or illness of the animal. 
The licensee must keep copies of medical records for dogs that name all vaccines and treatments administered and the 
dates of administration. To be corrected from this day forward: April 16, 2025.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
